repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Northwest Frontier Province
            On-Farm Water Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the North West Frontier
            Province (NWFP) On-Farm Water Management Project for
            Pakistan were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: For projects of
            this level of complexity, a full time project director and
            more structured project management unit with adequate
            staffing will be essential. Projects, which envisage a major
            institutional development component entailing beneficiary
            participation, will require a sufficient lead time before
            the physical investment activities start to allow adequate
            social mobilization process. At design stage, the project
            risks should be properly assessed, especially in terms of
            its broader policy environment and political commitments of
            the Government. For effective implementation of financial
            management system, the donor agencies reporting requirements
            need be harmonized and aligned to the borrower's
            accounting system and the counterpart accounting staff and
            independent auditors should be given adequate training.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - North West Frontier Province
            On-Farm Water Management Project, and Second North West
            Frontier Province Community Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed additional credit and the
            reallocated amount for Pakistan will help finance the costs
            associated with the new activities that include, (i) repairs
            of breaches in canal embankments, removal of debris
            deposited in the canal prisms and repair of control
            structures, drainage structures and water storage
            infrastructure; (ii) re construction and/r repairs of
            damaged roads, culverts and bridges; (iii) repair and/or
            reconstruction of public buildings such as schools, health
            facilities and buildings; (iv) repair of damaged drinking
            water supply and sanitation systems; and (v) assisting
            households and families to reestablish their livelihood by
            helping in the reconstruction of their houses, restarting
            their agricultural activities by providing agricultural
            technology packages, restocking their livestock devastated
            by the floods and earthquake and providing livelihood
            support to households and individuals affected by the
            disaster. There will be no change to the ongoing project activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Northwest Frontier Province
            (NWFP) On-Farm Water Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The North West Frontier Province (NWFP)
            On-Farm Water Management Project, aims at reducing rural
            poverty through increased agricultural production, and
            increased farm incomes. The components will cover aspects of
            both the NWFP and the Federally Administered Tribal Areas
            (FATA) as follows. 1) The community development and support
            program, will cover essential aspects of irrigation
            management, namely, through the operation of the system;
            collection of water charges; system maintenance; and,
            rehabilitation, and improvement works. 2) The distributary
            level improvement program, includes the establishment of
            offices, supported by technical assistance (TA) to improve
            the canal system, and, by the repair of distributary gates,
            rehabilitation of diversion structures, and, improvement of
            critical sections of the canal, which includes discharges,
            water measuring structures, and gauges. 3) The watercourse,
            and on-farm improvements program will allocate investments,
            focusing on the realignment of irrigation water to improve
            conveyance of the canal water, and reduce channel
            deterioration, and water losses. Storage tanks will be
            constructed; irrigated land will undergo precision land
            leveling in the canal command, and barani area; and,
            demonstration centers will be in place to expose sustainable
            soil, and water management practices. 4) Improvements in
            branch, and distributary canal systems will support farmer
            organizations, and the Federation of Water User Association,
            to include cross regulators, falls, and embankments
            rehabilitation. 5) The local/minor irrigation schemes
            development program will improve intermittent, non-perennial
            streams through appropriate engineering designs, and
            rehabilitation; and, 6) Project management support will be
            provided for supervision, monitoring/evaluation, and TA, and
            training support.
